key_title: Key to the species of Monotoca

source.author: Albrecht, D.E.
source.title: Epacridaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: From: Albrecht, D.E. (1996). Epacridaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Leaf apex usually pungent with a mucro 0.2–1.7 mm long; leaves usually more than 6 mm long, but if shorter then narrow-oblong, lanceolate or elliptic when flattened; small shrubs to small trees
Leaf apex with a blunt callous point; leaves 1.8–6 mm long, broadly elliptic-ovate to broadly oblong when flattened; shrub to 30 cm high, confined to Brumby Point on Nunniong Plateau

Flowers solitary in bract axils of current season\'s growth and/or in racemes in the upper leaf axils of previous season\'s growth; racemes (when present) with distinctly pedicellate flowers subtended for the most part by scarious caducous bracts most of which are more than 1.3 mm long (the distal-most sometimes persistent and becoming leaf-like); ripe fruit red-orange

At least some of the inflorescences produced in the bract axils of current growth spicate; racemes always absent; individual flowers subtended by small persistent bracts less than 1.3 mm long; fruit greyish, yellow or red-orange when ripe

Leaves 9–23 mm long, 2.4–6.5 mm wide; corolla tube of male flowers (0.8–)l-1.5 mm long; female corolla tube 0.5–1 mm long; anthers (1.1–) 1.2–1.9 mm long; all or most flowering axes not continuing terminal vegetative growth beyond the flowering region; plant of near-coastal areas, flowering Jun.-Sep

Leaves 3.8–11 mm long, 1.4–2.8 mm wide; corolla tube of male flowers 0.4–0.8 mm long; female corolla tube 0.4–0.6 mm long; anthers 0.8–1.2 (–1.3) mm long; all or most flowering axes continuing terminal vegetative growth beyond the flowering region (while plants flowering); plant of montane-subalpine areas, flowering Nov.-Jan

Lowermost spikes lacking or rarely with 1 sterile bract; lowermost spikes with peduncle (0.4–) 0.8–3.2 mm long; leaves usually 2.3–5 mm wide; non-lignotuberous shrubs or small trees frequently higher than 2m

Lowermost spikes with 1–4 (usually 2) inconspicuous basal or subbasal sterile bracts; lowermost spikes with peduncle wanting or occasionally to 0.6 mm long; leaves usually 1.3–2.6 mm wide; lignotuberous shrub to 2 m high
Corolla of male flowers 2.5–3 mm long; female corolla 1.6–2.2 mm long; anthers 1.3–1.8 mm long; distal leaves with petioles glabrous abaxially; fruit red-orange when fully ripe; Grampians endemic

Corolla of male flowers 1.5–2.2 mm long; female corolla 1.2–1.8 mm long; anthers 0.6–1.1 mm long; distal leaves with petioles usually puberulent abaxially; fruit translucent greyish when fully ripe; scattered in southern Victoria
